text.content:
This is a FoundryVTT system for Mongoose Traveller 2e. It provides character sheets and support for game rules. The core system does not contain much in the way of 'content', in the form of equipment lists.

The below documentation covers how to use the Foundry System with Traveller. It doesn't describe the Traveller rules themselves.

Contents

@UUID[.mXeFfBZITS7IkfPU]{Recent Changes} - List of changes to the system

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.V8trIYLYHch6WjEo]{Getting Started} - Help and guides for new Referees and Players

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.daLn8GLKHRgnJBax]{Chat Commands} - Macros and chat commands that are built in

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.XqtcLHYC383iXuNo]{Spacecraft}

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.b3GTINzvb5g0tz9H]{Core Rules} - Overview of which Traveller rules are implemented in Foundry

Further Help

If you have questions, bugs or need help, then there are a couple of good places to go:

  • GitHub Issue Tracker

  • Traveller Discord

There are a number of Compendium packs included with the system. The content of these may change when the system is updated. They can be recognise by having a "MgT2e Base" prefix.

Base Compendiums

The base compendiums are as follows. All have the "MgT2e Base" prefix. Access them via the Compendium Packs tab on the right sidebar.

Actors

Currently just contains a package for a @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-actors.Actor.Fq5fsrvRAEXRxurY]{Standard Human Character}.

Docs

This documentation.

Items

Contains a list of basic items.

  • Crew Roles - some basic crew roles for spacecraft.

  • Software - basic software items available on every spaceship.

    • @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-items.Item.pCFl4KSmPoTd5hdn]{Intellect}

    • @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-items.Item.EX9sxKi5tfSUyDUg]{Library}

    • @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-items.Item.sY0q0A4I5hcrxTil]{Manoeuvre}

  • Trade Goods - items representing the full list of trade goods used in Mongoose Traveller. These can be added to a ship when running trade missions. They are also used by the world trade rules. If you

  • Weapons - a list of unarmed and natural attack types for adding to a character.

    • @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-items.Item.KjYQNF4VI3GigmEy]{Bite and Claw}

    • @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-items.Item.uTtH5mXI2i0byiXO]{Unarmed}

Macros

This contains some basic macros which can be used for inspiration or as examples. They will be updated whenever the system is updated. You will need to drag them out into the macro folder (or just drag them to the hot bar) in order to use them.

For example:

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-macros.Macro.c0VzdYaCOk0lsx9W]{1D6}

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-macros.Macro.pjNaPg3jnqwq0ws7]{2D6}

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-macros.Macro.pBJCMW5TZAb9pmuw]{D66}

The MgT2e system comes with a number of assets included, to aid in running a game of Traveller. Some of these are tokens, others are icons, or artwork to decorate a landing page with.

Images

Within the systems/mgt2e/images/ folder are a number of tokens.

Spacecraft

There are tokens available for some of the most common spacecraft found in the Third Imperium. These are each available in eight different shades. Each of the ships described in the core rules are included. Tokens for other ships will eventually be available in the High Guard supplement.

The tokens are not drawn to a linear scale. Larger ships will have a larger token, but the scale is logarithmic. A ship that is less than 30t has a token 256px (designed to be one square) wide. Every ten fold increase in mass increases the size of the token by 2 squares.

This token size isn't enforced, but gives a reasonable indication of the size of vessels when using the tokens on a map for spacecombat.

Spacecraft Tonnage

Token Size

1-29t

1x1 square

30-99t

2x2 squares

100-299t

3x3 squares

300-999t

4x4 squares

1,000t+

5x5 squares

Note that these tokens are scaled down from the original SVG artwork, where they are sized at 256px per 1.5m for character scale.

The original art is available available here.

Vehicles

Vehicle tokens are also provided. These are also at 256px per square, and available in a range of colours. These are sized to fit alongside character tokens on a map, so use 1.5m per 256px. Many are based on the vehicles described in the core rules. Actual sizes aren't give, so the token sizes are very much a guess based on what seems reasonable. Unlike the spacecraft, the vehicles aren't all square tokens, but rectangular.

Icons

Icons are designed for items or as graphical icons.

Welcome to the latest update to Mongoose Traveller 2e. The full list of changes can be found in the release notes: Latest Changes

For general documentation, see the internal journal pages here: @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.83nkkP7aeGF22kG6]{Documentation}

Recent Changes

  • Added option to modify the rules for speculative trade. Two roll tables can be added to a world (examples are included in the compendium) to modify the buy/sell DMs to make trade easier or harder.

    • @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-tables.RollTable.zsNYgBxi8BuMwzsI]{Trade Buy Modifiers}

    • @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-tables.RollTable.URaBZYegz9Y5hUlF]{Trade Sell Modifiers}

  • Worlds now show if they have refined/unrefined fuel. Added option to buy fuel from worlds, and automatically refuel spacecraft.

  • Support for Spacechip Criticals against crew members. Damage is applied to random occupants of the ship.

  • Critical hit results are now output to the chat, not just as notifications. Switched to using templating for this, to make the code nicer.

  • Updated the skill checks to use templating, and updated the look and feel of skill checks to hopefully give them a cleaner look.

  • Traveller 'Player Name' field now shows a drop down list of all the players in the game, allowing quick selection.

  • Added @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.b3GTINzvb5g0tz9H.JournalEntryPage.KlmiZrvBGDx1E0BL#applying-damage]{mechanism} to allow damage handling to be passed to a user (usually the GM) who owns a token or actor, rather than simply raising a 'no permission' error. Damage to player owned Travellers can be passed to the player to handle, even when the GM has permission to do so.

  • On first start, a new default Traveller landing page will be created.

  • Support will soon be dropped for FoundryVTT 12.

There are multiple types of actors, some of which are designed to be used for characters and creatures within the game world whilst others are meta objects to be used as templates.

Travellers, NPCs, Creatures and Packages are considered to be 'characters'. Spacecraft, VehiclesÂ and Worlds are considered a different type of Actor, and how Items are treated when added to them can be different.

Character Types

Traveller

Travellers represent player characters.

  • Full list of characteristics

  • Full list of skills

  • Damage is applied to characteristics

  • Equipment can be assigned

  • Has a full career history

A Traveller will be given a random space man icon on creation.

NPC

NPCs are simplified versions of Travellers, designed to be used for less important characters.

  • Full list of characteristics

  • Full list of skills

  • Simplified character sheet with no career history.

  • Optionally damage can be simplified to a single HITS attribute.

An NPC will be given a random space man icon on creation.

An NPC has an alternative character sheet which is even simpler.

Creature

Creatures represent animals which lack human intelligence.

  • Have no characteristics

  • Have a limited set of skills

  • Damage is applied to a unified HITS total

A Creature will be given a random Creature icon on creation.

Package

A package is a template that can be applied to a Traveller or NPC. They can be used to define simplified career packages (such as those found in the Traveller Companion), or used to set up custom packages of skills to quickly build up NPCs. Dragging a Package on top of a Traveller or NPC character sheet will copy skills, items and other attributes onto the destination character.

A Package is given a grey space man icon on creation.

It is recommended that a Career Term is given to a package. This will be copied to the destination Traveller or NPC and provide a record of which packages have been used.

Characteristics are specified as modifiers (-1 / 0 / +2 etc), and will modify the UPP of the destination character.

If the Racial Package option is ticked, than rather than applying modifiers to existing characteristics, completely new characteristics will be rolled when the package is applied. It defaults to using 2D6, but other values for non-humans can be specified. These support the full range of Foundry dice options, so it is possible to specify 3D6k2 for more 'heroic' characteristics, or 3D6kl2 for lower values.

Height and Weight

If the package has non-zero height and weight set, then a random height and weight will be automatically set on the target actor modified by physical characteristics. This can be changed afterwards by the player, and should only be used as a very rough suggestion. Mostly it is so that NPCs don't all have the same boring default values.

Weight is modified upwards by STR and END, downwards by DEX.

Height is modified upwards by STR.

If the actor's gender is set to Male, then both are modified upwards. If they are defined as Female, then height and weight are modified downwards. Other values in the gender field have no effect.

Spacecraft

Spacecraft Tokens

A number of tokens are available for some of the most common spaceships in Traveller. Each is available in a range of different colours.

If you want to use them as actual tokens, the size of each token is scaled according to the size of the ship.

The smallest ship are designed for use as 1x1 tokens, 30t or larger are 2x2, 100t or larger are 3x3 and 300t or larger are 4x4.

Spacecraft represent both smallcraft and starships. Their character sheet is design to represent a space craft, and it has several panels for different types of items:

  • The Ship's Locker contains typical Traveller equipment, including weapons and armour.

  • The Cargo Hold contains anything which is 'Cargo'.

  • Hardware contains actual ship's hardware, such as jump drives, turrets, power plants and the like.

Cargo and Hardware need to be created as standalone items before they can be added to a Spacecraft.

Crew Roles

Crew, in the form of Travellers and NPCs, can be added to the ship by dragging their actor to it. This will initially be added as Passengers, but can be promoted to crew by clicking the icon on their card.

Clicking on a crew or passenger's portrait will open their full character sheet. Otherwise you can click the edit button to assign them to roles aboard the ship. Roles have to be first added to the ship, by dragging a 'Crew Role' item to it.

A role can define a number of actions that crew members with that role can perform.

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.XqtcLHYC383iXuNo.JournalEntryPage.M6w2juT3bwCbEXdU#creating-a-role]{Creating a Role}

Weapons

Weapon items which have a scale of 'Starship' are added to a spacecraft as potential weapon systems rather than put in the ship's locker. They can then assigned to weapon mounts which are defined by Starship Hardware.

@UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.traveller-docs.JournalEntry.XqtcLHYC383iXuNo.JournalEntryPage.qLZ9BdVEeSIbwc57]{Spacecraft Weapons}

Spacecraft are currently partially supported, so not all features are complete.

Swarm

A swarm represents a group of smaller things, and is currently used to represent either a Missile Salvo or a Fighter Squadron. Support for these is currently in progress, though the missile salvos should be working well enough to be usable.

Note that Swarms aren't designed to be created from the drop down menu. If you do, you will currently be given an option to create a fighter squadron.

Making a missile attack from a spacecraft will automatically create a missile salvo actor, and setup the prototype token so that it can be dragged to the scene.

World

Worlds are an Actor type which represent worlds and systems within the game. Traveller mixes the idea of a 'World' and a 'Star System' together, and the same is done here.

By default, when a World actor is created, its prototype token is defined as being linked to the Actor object.

To be useful, Worlds need to be visible to players. However, they don't need write permissions in order to use most of their facilities as long as the GM is online.

Trade

The Mongoose Traveller trade system is implemented within Foundry. The idea is that players should for the most part be able to manage trade themselves, without having to refer to the GM.

Unless a player has write permission to a world, a GM does need to be logged in whilst trade is being performed. The GM is also needed to 're-roll' what trade goods are available.

Creating A Character

When a new character is created, you are presented with a basic character sheet, which will look something like the following. If you are creating an NPC, the character will be slightly different, but the overall is the same.

The standard six characteristics are displayed near the top, along with a Roll Characteristics icon. Clicking this will roll 2D6 for each of your characteristics. You can click this to re-roll if you want, plus you can drag the characteristic values around to swap them over. Once you have the characteristics you want (or the GM tells you to stop re-rolling), you can disable the button by ticking the 'Lock UPP' option under Settings.

If you shift-click the roll button, then you will get a more average set of characteristics. If you ctrl-click it, then the current characteristics will be varied slightly. These two options are mostly of use for NPCs.

Modifying your characteristics in these ways will output the changes to the chat.

The Damage Stats box allows you to control which characteristics can take damage. Click the cog icon to select or deselect your options. The three core physical characteristics of STR, DEX and END will always be displayed for Travellers.

The Sheet Tabs allow you to choose which details you want to display.

  • Skills - The default, shows your characters' skills, and allows you to roll and modify them.

  • Equipment - What you are carrying, wearing or own.

  • Finance - Financial information about your character.

  • Biography - A place to write a description of your character, plus some background details.

  • History - A place to record what the character did during their life path process.

  • Settings - General settings for the character.

The Skill Filters options allow you to hide skills. Trained only will display only skills you are trained in. Background will just display the background skill options which are taken at the start of character generation.

The Skills tab lists all the skills available to you. Some skills are only displayed if certain characteristics are enabled. For example, the Psionic talents are hidden unless the PSI characteristic is enabled.

As for Actors, there are multiple types of Items. Items in MgT2e can be divided into three broad categories:

Carried Items: These are items which can be carried and used by character. They are personal items, which can be used by people (Travellers, NPCs, Creatures or Packages).

Spacecraft Items: These are items which are used by spacecraft. They can't be given to characters (Travellers, NPCs, Creatures or Packages). As for Carried Items though, they represent physical things in the world.

Meta Items: These represet more nebulous things on a character sheet, and may not be things in the real world.

Carried Items

These are physical items that can be carried by Travellers and NPCs. They have a weight and to an actor's encumbrance.

Each carried item has a Tech Level, Cost and Weight.

Such items have three possible states on the actor sheet:

Active - Worn or held in the hand. These are ready to be used.

Carried - Being carried, but not in use.

Stored - These are owned by the Traveller, but not currently 'at hand'.

Armour

Armour adds a to an actor's ability to resist damage. Normally, only one item or armour can be worn at a time. Wearing an item of armour when one is already being worn will move the other to 'carried'.

Armour has a protection and a 'other protection' score. The latter is added to the base protection if the attack type of the weapon (laser, energy, fire) matches one of the energy types listed for the armour.

Augmentation

Augmentations give bonuses to an actor, in the form of bonuses to characteristics or skills. They are normally cyberware or biological implants or drugs. There are several types, which vary by how they add bonuses.

Skill and Characteristic Effects

Augment - Increases a characteristic or skill by the given value. The character must already have the skill at 0 for an augment to work.

DM - Adds a bonus or penalty to rolls involving the characteristic or skill. The bonus applies regardless of the skill level of the character.

Boon / Bane - Causes rolls for this characteristic or skill to be rolled with a boon or a bane.

Expert Program - Follows the rules of expert software. Level X gives a skill level of X-1.

Min - Sets the minimum value for a characteristic. Applied after Augment bonus.

Other Effects

Carry Multiplier - Increases the multiple of how much the character can carry. A value of +1 will double max load (x1 -> x2).

Encumbrance DM - Usually a penalty, applied to all physical skill checks.

Physical DM - Applied to physical skill checks

Melee DM - Applied to attacks with Melee skills. It does not apply to pure skill checks.

Gun Combat DM - Provides a bonus to gun skills when making an attack. It does not apply to pure skill checks.

Note that currently Augments aren't really needed. Now that Active Effects can be added to other item types, the need for them isn't so great. However, they are still kept around and maybe conceptually they are different from other items.

At some point, Augments might be considered as 'inherent' bonuses, rather than as physical items.

General Items

These are generic items which don't have any special rules implemented in the game world. They have a weight, cost and TL, but normally not much else.

However, General Items, as well as some other item types have two optional extras:

  • They can have effects applied to them, turning them into Augments.

  • They can have a computer embedded in them, allowing software to be installed on them.

Software

Software are a type of item that can be installed on items which have an embedded computer. They can also be installed on Spacecraft.

Unlike Augments, they don't automatically add bonuses to skills. Instead, you open up your computer and use them from there.

Weapon

Weapons appear in the list of attack items. Weapons have a scale, which is either Traveller, Vehicle or Starship. This affects what type of actor can use it.

Weapons can have traits, which may have an effect on the attack. The following traits are currently supported:

AP, Auto, Blast, Bulky, Destructive, LaserSight, Lo-Pen, Radiation, Scope, Smart, Stun, VeryBulky, Zero-G

The ones listed in bold have automated support. The others are currently just informational.

Spacecraft Items

These items cannot be carried by a person.

Cargo

Freight and speculative trade items which can be traded and sold. Normally, Cargo is created on Worlds, and dragged onto a Spacecraft sheet to purchase it. It can then be dragged onto another World sheet to sell it.

Hardware

Spacecraft hardware, such as jump drives, weapons and power systems. Hardware can only be added to spacecraft actor sheets.

Meta Items

Such items represent things on the character sheet, but aren't physical things in the world.

Associate

An ally, enemy, contact or rival that is gained during character generation. They represent an NPC, but don't have any NPC type statistics.

Term

A carerr term during character generation.

World Data

A multi-purpose item that is used to represent something on a world. Currently, they cover passengers and factions.

Weapons

Weapons are a special type of item, and each weapon can have one or more traits applied to them. The following weapon traits have rules implemented to handle them automatically.

Traits

AP (X)

Reduces the protective value of the target's armour.

AUTO (X)

Automatic weapon. Allows weapons to be fired in burst or full auto mode when an attack is made, either making multiple attacks or giving a bonus to damage. Ammunition is reduced by the auto value.

BLAST (X)

Causes blast damage. If the damage value is dragged to a map, then the blast area of effect will be displayed on the map. There are system options to apply a 'jitter' to the location if the attack misses.

BULKY

Gives a penalty to attack rolls if Traveller's strength is < 9.

DANGEROUS

A message will be output if the weapon explodes.

DESTRUCTIVE

Multiplies the damage (and effect) done by 10.

LO-PEN (X)

Multiplies target's protection by the lo-pen value.

ONE USE

After an attack is made, the quantity of this weapon is reduced by one. Useful for grenades or other weapons which have a single use.

PROTECTION (X)

Provides armour to the Traveller whilst the weapon is active. This stacks with all other types of armour. Provided by some types of shields.

RADIATION

Does radiation damage. This will be listed in the damage output, and applied to Travellers when the damage is dragged to their sheet.

PSI AP (X)

The AP of the weapon is equal to the PSI DM of the wielder times X. Extra PSI points can be spent to increase the AP by X.

PSI DAMAGE (X)

If PSI DM is greater than zero, then this multiplied by X is added as a damage bonus. This is in addition to any damage bonus from STR.

Psi Points can be spent to increase damage, each point does a further X damage.

Note that the behaviour of Psi Damage > 1 has been extrapolated from the rules for Psi AP.

SHIELD (X)

Uses the shield rules. Melee is minimum of the user's weapon skill and the shield skill when making a parry. You should also set the parry score for the weapon. The Shield (X) does not add a parry bonus, it just sets a minimum for the melee skill.

Most shields have Shield (0) and Parry +1

STUN

Does stun damage.

VERY BULKY

Gives a penalty to using a weapon is STR is less than 12.
